awd_titl_txt: Quantifying Entrainment and its Effects in Isolated, Sheared Cumuli and Thunderstorms
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's precipitation is primarily produced by deep cumulus clouds.  Many aspects of cumulus convection are affected by entrainment, the process by which turbulent clouds introduce dry air from outside the cloud.  Entrainment results in the dilution of the cloud which decreases the updraft speed and cloud height, and potentially prevents precipitation formation.  This award will provide funding for the systematic investigation of entrainment in storms that occur in regions with environmental wind shear, the conditions that can sustain supercell thunderstorms.  The researcher plans to develop general relationships between wind shear, cumulus entrainment, and convective precipitation which can be used to improve prediction of thunderstorm initiation, and rain, hail and lightning that form within these storms.  In addition, the project will contribute to the development of two early-career researchers who will be trained in atmospheric science and high performance computing.

Prior research on cumulus entrainment has largely not taken wind shear into consideration.  This project will use the CM1 cloud model to address three main hypotheses:  1) Unidirectional vertical wind shear enhances entrainment (compared to the non-sheared case) into a cloud updraft in its thermal-like stage, but directional vertical wind shear decreases this enhancement, 2) In environments with sufficiently strong vertical wind shear to generate a rotating updraft, the thermal-like initial updraft transforms into a jet-like updraft, decreasing the entrainment into, and dilution of, the rotating updraft, 3) The increased entrainment and dilution into a cloud updraft in its thermal stage, and the decreased entrainment and dilution of the jet stage results in non-negligible (>10%) decreases and increases (respectively) in precipitation production within the storm.

por.por_cntn:
Supercell thunderstorms contain cores that rotate in a counter-clockwise direction, and these storms are associated with significant weather hazards such as heavy rainfall, hail and/or tornadoes which can lead to loss of life and destruction of property. Entrainment is the introduction of dry air from outside the storm to its interior.  It is one process that can modulate the intensity of supercells, and a better understanding of its impact could help improve thunderstorm forecasts and especially the precipitation they produce.  Before this study was performed, little was known about how, i.e., the mechanisms by which, supercell thunderstorms entrain, and the extent to which air inside the storm is diluted, i.e., mixes with air outside the storm and is thus cooler and drier.  It is nearly impossible at the current time to collect observations of entrainment in thunderstorms, and so numerical simulations are a viable avenue to make some headway in advancing current knowledge.

In this study, for the first time, various mechanisms of entrainment occurring during the developing and mature stages of idealized supercell thunderstorms have been identified, examined and quantified.  Entrainment is calculated directly as fluxes of air over the surface of the storm updraft core. Dilution is quantified by inserting passive tracers into the simulation to detect the amount of mixing with environmental air.  As various factors of the storm environment were changed in the simulations, the impact on entrainment, dilution, precipitation production within the storm, and rainfall at the ground, were quantified to study relationships among them.

In the developing stage, before the supercell thunderstorm core rotates, the greatest entrainment rates result from the asymmetric overturning of large eddies near cloud top on the downwind side. These rates are greater than those published in the literature for cumuli developing in environments lacking strong vertical wind shear (i.e., strong changes in wind direction and/or wind speed with altitude). Although the entrainment rate increases exponentially in time throughout the developing stage, successive cloud turrets help to replenish some of the lost buoyancy and cloud water and ice, allowing the nascent storm to develop further.

During the mature stage, the greatest entrainment rates occur via ribbons of horizontal vorticity wrapping around the rotating updraft that ascend in time (shown in the accompanying image near the middle and bottom of the core), a mechanism that was heretofore unknown. Another mechanism consists of disorganized turbulent eddies (shown in the image near the top of the core). These two entrainment mechanisms reduce the ability of the storms to produce precipitation by diluting the warm moist air ingested by the storm.The smaller width of the ribbons and turbulent eddies in comparison to the wider storm core limits their dilutive effects, however. A third mechanism, the storm relative airstream, actually supplies additional moisture into the storm updraft to enhance precipitation production. Passive tracers placed in the simulations lindicate that on average 20% of the supercell core contains some undiluted air from below the storm base, unaffected by any entrainment mechanism.   

Although the total entrainment added up over the storm core increases with increasing vertical wind shear in the storm environment, the width of the storm core also increases, resulting in an increase in undiluted air within the storm core and thereby an increase in precipitation produced inside the storm. However, increased vertical wind shear in the storm environment also increases the precipitation ejected out the top of the storm, enhancing its evaporation as it falls toward the ground.  As a result, less precipitation falls to the ground with increasing vertical wind shear, as suggested in past studies.

If the storm environment is made drier at mid-to-upper altitudes, the drier entrained air seems to have little impact upon precipitation production inside the storm, but the evaporation of precipitation falling outside the storm is again enhanced, and therefore also decreases the precipitation reaching the ground. If instead the storm environment is made drier at lower altitudes only, the moist air entrained by the storm-relative airstream is reduced, which weakens the supercell updraft and also the precipitation that it produces.

These results are the first comprehensive quantification of the various ways that supercell thunderstorms entrain, and their impact on precipitation in supercell thunderstorms.  In time, and with further investigation, such quantification may help increase the accuracy of forecasts of supercell hazards to society.
